text: Do we distribute any GPL code via BinaryBuilder ? <@U679VPJ8L> was thinking it may be useful to distribute OpenJDK, but I just wanted to be careful about the licensing implications. I was wondering if there was already precedent.

elements.text: Do we distribute any GPL code via BinaryBuilder ?
was thinking it may be useful to distribute OpenJDK, but I just wanted to be careful about the licensing implications. I was wondering if there was already precedent.

text: as long the software is redistributable in binary form, it's fine

elements.text: as long the software is redistributable in binary form, it's fine

text: (but I'm a bit wary of providing the runtime of other languages)

elements.text: (but I'm a bit wary of providing the runtime of other languages)

text: There's that, but I'm just wondering about navigating the viral nature of the GPL. JavaCall.jl is current under MIT License. Arguably, when someone dynamically links a library under GPL, then the person who does that must distribute the combined work under GPL.

elements.text: There's that, but I'm just wondering about navigating the viral nature of the GPL. JavaCall.jl is current under MIT License. Arguably, when someone dynamically links a library under GPL, then the person who does that must distribute the combined work under GPL.

text:
I'm wondering how other permissively licensed packages manage their dependencies on copyleft licensed packages.

Ok that's a great example.
